file_name: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad _ Kaspersky ICS CERT

sentences.1: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.7: In mid-October 2021 Kaspersky ICS CERT researchers uncovered an active ShadowPadbackdoor infection on industrial control systems (ICS) in Pakistan.
sentences.13: Some of the victim organizations were breached by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855vulnerability in Microsoft Exchange.
sentences.15: From March to October 2021, the ShadowPad backdoor was downloaded to victimcomputers as the mscoree.dll file, which was launched by AppLaunch.exe – aperfectly legitimate application.Later the attackers launched ShadowPad using DLL hijacking in a legitimate OLE-COM object viewing application (OleView).After the initial infection the attackers first sent commands manually, thenautomatically.Other tools were also used:
sentences.16: The CobaltStrike framework, which was downloaded to victim machines usingthe certutil.exe utility, compiled aspx web shells, and procdump and Mimikatztools;The PlugX backdoor;BAT files (for stealing credentials);Web shells (for remote access to the web server);The Nextnet utility (for scanning network hosts).
sentences.17: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.18: The attackers used domains registered with NameSilo, GoDaddy.com and ENOM tocommunicate with the command-and-control (C2) servers.
sentences.19: Most of the C2 servers werehosted on dedicated servers rented from Choopa.
sentences.26: In mid-October 2021, Kaspersky ICS CERT experts discovered an active ShadowPadbackdoor that affected a number of industrial control systems in Pakistan, specificallyengineering computers in building automation systems that are part of a telecomcompany’s infrastructure.
sentences.29: The attackers exploited a known vulnerability in MS Exchange, CVE-2021-26855, as theinitial attack vector in several victim organizations.
sentences.30: We do not have evidence that CVE-2021-26855 was exploited in all cases of attack identified, but we can assume that theattackers could use this particular vector to penetrate in other cases, as well.
sentences.34: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.35: Export table of the mscoree.dll (ShadowPad) maliciouis DLL
sentences.36: In some of the cases we studied at the same time, we found that a ShadowPad sample thathad the same name and launching scheme was executed by exploiting the MS ExchangeCVE-2021-26855 vulnerability.
sentences.37: Since about mid-October 2021, a new ShadowPad launching scheme and a new version ofthe malware has been used targeting the same organizations.
sentences.38: Instead of usingmscoree.dll, the attackers switched to using the dll hijacking technique in legitimatesoftware for viewing OLE-COM objects (OleView).
sentences.39: The legitimate OleView applicationdownloads the malicious IVIEWERS.dll library, which in turn downloads and executesthe ShadowPad payload contained in IVIEWERS.dll.dat.
sentences.44: We found that on a subset of computers (at least one in each attacked organization’snetwork), some series of commands had been remotely executed via the command lineinterface (cmd.exe).
sentences.46: The list of commands executed by the attackers manually is shown in the originalsequence in the table below.
sentences.47: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.75: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.77: It is important to note that this part of the TTPs is quite unique and we believe it supportsattributing all cases of similar activity to one Chinese-speaking group of attackers.
sentences.82: The attackers used CobaltStrike, which was downloaded to the victim’s computer usingthe certutil.exe utility, compiled aspx webshells, the procdump tool, and Mimikatz.
sentences.83: CobaltStrike was downloaded using the following command:
sentences.88: In addition to the ShadowPad backdoor, activity associated with downloading aro.dat, avariant of the PlugX backdoor, using bitsadmin was identified on the server of one of thevictims.
sentences.94: Bat file found on a victim’s server
sentences.95: The contents of this file are very similar to the bat file described in a VB article, whichmentions that the script was used by the Chinese group HAFNIUM.
sentences.98: These are compiled .NETAssembly files for aspx scripts used by the actor for remote access to the web server(webshell).
sentences.101: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.104: The ShadowPad CnC servers found are mostly hosted on rented dedicated Choopaservers.
sentences.150: We believe with a high degree of confidence that a Chinese-speaking threat actor isbehind the activity described in this report.
sentences.152: Attacks on industrial control systems using ShadowPad | Kaspersky ICS CERT
sentences.153: The Mimikatz utility (m1.log, SHA256:30a78770615c6b42c17900c4ad03a9b708dc2d9b743bbdc51218597518749382),which was identified during our investigation on computers of organizations inPakistan, Malaysia, and Afghanistan, was also mentioned in a Symantec report.
sentences.154: Thereport also claims that the threat actor HAFNIUM was involved in attacksexploiting a Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerability.In addition, a bat file for stealing NTLM hashes of accounts was found on a server ofone of the victims.
sentences.156: Activity related to downloading the PlugX backdoor (aro.dat), which occurred on theserver of one of the victims, was analyzed in the Palo Alto Networks report, which allegesthe involvement of a Chinese group known as PKPLUG.

sentences.262: The attacker creates scheduled tasks to set up dailyexecution of malicious payloads.
sentences.265: BITS Jobs The attacker uses a BITS job to download additionalpayloads.
sentences.272: T1574.002 Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Side-Loading
sentences.276: File and Directory Discovery The attacker lists files and directories available on infectedsystems.

sentences.285: T1560.002 Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
sentences.287: T1560.002 Archive Collected Data: Archive via Library
sentences.291: Automated Collection The attacker automatically collects a list of files andconnected USB devices.
sentences.292: Data from Local System The attacker uses a PowerShell script to collect Officedocuments on the local system.
sentences.293: T1114.001 Email Collection: Local Email Collection
sentences.296: T1071.001 Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
sentences.306: Automated Exfiltration The attacker can automatically exfiltrate Office documents.
sentences.308: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel The attacker exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.
sentences.310: Storage The attacker exfiltrates data to Google Drive.
